questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-


Guidelines
-

This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary pre-configurations have been applied.
• Do not remove any existing configurations from the devices, only those necessary to make the appropriate changes required to fulfill the listed tasks.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab closes and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-


Task 1
-

• Configure a host route on R5 for the destination of 10.200.220.6.
• Configure a static default route on R1 preferring the path through R3 towards R6.
• From R5, use traceroute and ping to verify the path towards and reachability of R6.


Task 2
-

• Configure a floating static default route on R1, preferring the path through R2 towards R6 if the link to R3 should fail.
• Configure the administrative distance for 225.
• Configure a static route on R2 to forward the return traffic towards 10.100.110.0/25.
• After shutting interface e0/1 on R1, use traceroute and ping from R5 to verify path towards and reachability of R6.

discussion.content:
Task-1
R5
conf t
ip route 10.200.220.6 255.255.255.255 10.100.110.1
end
wr

R1
conf t
ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 10.133.13.3
end
wr

R5
ping 10.200.220.6
traceroute 10.200.220.6

Task-2
R1
conf t
ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 10.122.12.2 225
end
wr

R2
conf t
ip route 10.100.110.0 255.255.255.128 10.122.12.1
end
wr

R1
conf t
interface e0/1
shut
end
traceroute 10.200.220.6
ping 10.200.220.6
This won't work. Every router needs to be configured to form the whole router, not just R1 and R5, unless a dynamic routing protocol is running on these routers to share routes with each other.

comments.content:
the first task it says host route on R5 for the destination of 10.200.220.6 
so shouldn't we use the subnet mask for the destination not the host of R5 i think it's tricky wording

discussion.content: Answers are correct.

Selected Answer: BC
correct
correct
correct

choices.E: Only authentication provides supporting information for billing users.
choices.B: Only authentication challenges users for their credentials and returns a response.
choices.D: Only authentication records the duration of a user's connection.

questions.question_text: Which two statements distinguish authentication from accounting? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: the correct answer is sw 4..

comments.content: why there's no one answers a lot like before

discussion.content: B is the correct answer becasue of priority tie between s2 and s3, the other swithes priority is way high the lowest mac address wont have any effect

Selected Answer: B
stp uses lowest values always (this is the reason we always have examples of old switches with older (lower) mac addresses being connected to the network and taking over as root bridge)
answer is correct B. First two lowest priority tally and next lowest MAC

B) SW2 is correct, don't forget the stp priority is checked first then the lowest mac address if there's a tie. In this case there is a tie between Sw2 and Sw3 with both having priority 4096, between these two we check who has the lowest mac add which is SW2 so B is correct
correct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which switch in this configuration will be elected as the root bridge?


SW1: 0C:E4:82:33:62:23 -

SW2: 0C:0E:16:11:05:97 -

SW3: 0C:E0:16:1A:3C:9D -
SW4: 0C:00:18:A1:B3:19

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D) SW4 is correct, to determine root bridge first check lowest priority then lowest mac add

comments.content: Wrong...this is the second root bridge question in a row you are misleading ppl on, first we check lowest priority, it is tie between sw3 and 4 then we check between these 2 to see who has the lowest mac address

discussion.content: the correct answer is sw 2
correct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which switch in this configuration will be elected as the root bridge?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. All routers in the network are configured correctly, and the expected routes are being exchanged among the routers. Which set of routes are learned from neighbors and installed on router 2?

discussion.content: Isn't EIGRP out of scope of CCNA?

Selected Answer: A
Directly connected networks for R2:
10.22.1.0/24: This is the network directly connected to R2.
10.40.1.0/30: This is the network between R2 and its WAN connection.

Routes learned via neighbors:
10.139.2.0/30: This is the network between R71 and the WAN. It will be learned via the WAN.
10.2.191.0/30: This is the network between R40 and the WAN. It will be learned via the WAN.
10.129.9.0/23: This is the network behind R71. It will be learned via R71.
10.129.9.0/25: This is the network behind R40. It will be learned via R40.

comments.content:
remember that the route with the lowest administrative distance will be put into the routing table.
even though 10.129.9.0 and 10.40.1.0 are being shared in the ospf process, router 2 has already learned them as directly connected routes with a AD of 0. so when the router 2 receives an LSA with this information it disregards adding those networks through ospf (AD of 110) and keeps the directly connected routes (key is they are not learned from neighbors)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
OK why not also 10.129.9.0/23 are learned ?
correct
